TITLE: CAREER: An Integrated Research/Educational Plan for Advancing RF Superconductivity for Particle Accelerators

This proposal requests partial support for a program of research to systematically characterize the radio-frequency(RF) surface resistance of superconductors to advance superconducting microwave cavities for particle accelerators and for an education and outreach program involving community college faculty and students in the research. This will be carried out at the Cornell Laboratory for Accelerator-based Sciences and Education at Cornell University.

The ultimate performance of a superconducting radio-frequency (SRF) accelerating cavity is governed by two factors: the maximum accelerating gradient that can be achieved without electrical breakdown, and the cavity Q (or Quality factor) when operating near this maximum gradient. The higher the Q, the less power required to achieve the maximum gradient, and therefore the less cost to both construct and operate the accelerator. The optimal Q of a cavity at a given level of excitation is related to the RF surface resistance of the cavity wall material, and this surface resistance is in turn related to the maximum RF magnetic field at the surface in a way that is both very sample dependent and theoretically poorly understood. The focus of the proposed research program will be on studying the mechanisms that limit the intrinsic Q in SRF cavities, and ways to improve Q. The primary attention in studying these topics will be on the superconductor niobium, which is the material of choice today for SRF cavities. As a subsidiary topic the potential of the A-15 superconductor Nb3Sn for providing highest intrinsic quality factor cavities will be explored. In studying these topics it will be of critical importance to get statistically significant data. This proposal addresses this challenge by developing a host cavity for testing small material samples with fast turnaround.

A new generation of improved superconducting rf cavities would have transformative, broad impact across accelerator-based sciences and engineering by improving the energy reach, performance and scientific potential of future particle accelerators. These next generation accelerators will fulfill the needs for particle physics, nuclear physics, neutron science, X-ray science and free-electron lasers. In addition, this research provides for the education of future generations of accelerator scientists and engineers, which are in high demand. Finally, this proposal includes a program to provide research opportunities in the physical sciences specifically for community college students to encourage them to pursue careers in science, technology, or science education. This large and critical group of students usually has very limited or no access to cutting-edge research opportunities and the proposed pilot program addresses this well-recognized, but mostly unaddressed issue.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Accelerator physicists design and build some of the world’s largest and most complex machines. These powerful tools fulfill the needs of a broad variety of science fields, including high-energy physics, nuclear physics, neutron science and X-ray science. Over the last decades, accelerator-based sciences have expanded rapidly with more and more powerful accelerators, leading to a large number of important scientific discoveries, ranging from finding the building blocks of our world to 3-dimensional pictures of complex proteins. Future applications of accelerators in science, national security, and industry will require even more powerful particle accelerators providing higher beam currents and/or higher beam energies, while at the same time at reduced cost and increased energy efficiency. Superconducting radio-frequency (SRF) cavities operated at cryogenic temperatures are the workhorses in many particle accelerators. Electromagnetic fields inside these cavities accelerate the particle beam, while the superconducting walls of the cavities minimize dissipation by the RF fields in the walls and thereby allow for efficient energy use. Nevertheless, a new generation of SRF cavities with higher accelerating fields and even higher energy efficiency will be required to realize the energy reach, performance and scientific potential envisioned of future particle accelerators.      

Gaining a good fundamental understanding of RF superconductivity - and thus the sources that contribute to the losses by the RF fields in the superconducting walls and limit maximum fields - is the first critical step for future progress in superconducting RF technology. The major research outcome of this award is the development and successful commissioning of a novel system to measure the superconducting RF performance of small material samples with high precision when exposed to high magnetic fields at microwave frequencies. These sample host cavities achieve unprecedented performances, are now unique tools available to the community to study the microwave performance of niobium and compound RF superconductors. Using the sample host cavities, we identified improved preparation techniques suitable for SRF cavities of the future, focusing on the traditional superconductor niobium and the most promising alternative, Nb3Sn. We produced Nb3Sn via tin vapor diffusion into a niobium substrate, and showed good stoichiometry and high critical temperatures of 18K. We performed RF measurements on coated Nb3Sn samples and cavities, and reached very promising performance, with 4.2K operation being a factor of ~30 more efficient than traditional niobium cavities are at that temperature. Our Nb3Sn cavities are the first ever accelerator cavities made with an alternative superconductor that outperforms traditional niobium at usable gradients. This result is a critical step towards a next generation of SRF cavities with much improved cryogenic efficiency and higher operating temperatures, thereby avoiding complex and expensive superfluid liquid helium operation and slashing power requirements by more than 50%. 

This research project trained undergraduate and graduate students (27 in total) in the field of accelerator physics with its highly interdisciplinary research including much needed skills for the workforce in the 21st century. Training students in accelerator physics is overdue to ensure that the United States can keep its leadership in this important field. A pilot summer research program specifically designed for community collage students was established as part of this award, and was very well received.
